title: I want to want...
content:
Interesting question. I'm not really sure how to answer it, actually.

It's kind of challenging to discern what I've experienced that suggest there's something more from what I've come to believe as a matter of faith, and then whether I believe what I do because I necessarily want to...

God to me would be a unity of all existence, not something apart from us but something of which we are a part, as it were. It/he/she/they would not be a disembodied consciousness or some bearded fellow sitting on a cloud with a harp and lightning bolt, but the very universe itself, and whatever exists and doesn't exist beyond it, including us.

I don't think it's a matter of wanting to believe. Though there are many things that fall into this category, my belief in 'God' stems not from a need to justify my existence (an explanation that modern psychology seems to obsess over) but from the fact it makes sense in the context of my experiences blended with those of others that fall within my believability gauge, which is again fueled by previous experience.

On one level, I suppose I do want there to be a supreme being, and ultimate purpose to life, since that would mean we'll actually find an answer someday (and then probably decide to forget it again and play the game again). Then we may find a way to directly and collectively communicate with this higher nature and will find that all our religions stem from a common source and we'll have that much less to fight about.

If there is no god, we're doomed forever to argue about it (well, not so really forever, but at least for as long as we last).

However, the idea of existence looping endlessly seems somewhat depressing to me. What's the purpose in it if we're just going to end it and start afresh? I wanna keep playing! But then that's how life works, and that's how any endeavour or entertainment medium functions, is it not? So it shouldn't really seem as dismal as it does, should it? *shrugs*

We need a baseline for this poll before I vote, though, as LevelLord says. Do you refer to the God of any particular theism; or our particular understanding of what God means; or what we would hope God would be?Cave assectatorem Ductoris Alacris

title: For giving, for getting.
content:
Though I've found words are too limited to describe my beliefs I'll attempt to state how my understanding works at present.

[hr]LevelLord I've never got reincarnation; now that there are more people, where did the souls come from? Where will they go if the population crashes? Will everyone thus suffer an infinite amount? How does the process occur?
[hr]This is assuming the afterlife adheres to a linear system of time. It's (almost) impossible for us to imagine anything beyond it, but ultimately there is no difference between past, present and future. Thus, any spirit can select any moment in time to incarnate. In addition, there is no limit to the amount of instances the original consciousness can split itself into, and thus as many spirits as may be necessary at any one point in time can exist at once.

[hr]Djaser No life is fun because there are things you are looking foreward to, goals to reach. That's all over in heaven, you'll have everything you need there.
[hr]Not really. Ever heard of 'just being' and/or 'going with the flow'? It's really quite enjoyable, and makes things fall into place much easier.

I understand what you're saying, though. Life wouldn't be what it is without challenges. If everything was easy, and worked out for the best no matter what we chose to do, what would be the point of it all? The problem is, our general idea of 'challenging' involves fighting against our own self to get things 'done', trying to get past our habits, our emotions, our inhibitions.

This is the equivalent of banging your head against a wall that stands in our way, rather than finding a way around it in order to get on with our journey. There are far more interesting challenges out there.

[hr]najawa You make this really cool game... and you need beta testers. You release some of the code to some teens. Some sell the code, and betray you, but others don't. The ones that don't, you give them the full code.

Analogy explained; God sends us to earth with just a vauge partial example of heaven (earth). We either sqander our time here, or we are good stewards. The good stewards are rewarded.
[hr]Or perhaps more to the effect of this: we're all here to simply experience the world/game that we, as God, created/create/are creating. There is no higher or lower purpose than that. The good and the bad are necessary, as 'good' cannot be experienced as such unless there's something with which to compare it (this also means that nothing must somehow exist, which seems entirely against its definition, but that's an entirely different mindtrip again).

Hell is simply the process, either herenow or in the layers of reality above, around, within, where/what/how/ifever they are, of not being conscious of what we are creating in our lives. While we have complete freedom to manifest whatever we wish (which we have for the most part forgotten, out of necessity as part of the aforementioned dichotomy--knowing [gnosis] cannot exist without first notknowing [agnosis]) Godself will keep reminding usself of the lessons we have chosen to learn, the same circumstances will keep remanifesting, as long as we refuse to re-member--accept them back into ourselves.

Heaven is the complement of that process:
[hr]T.S. EliotWe shall not cease from exploration. And the end of all our exploring will be to arrive where we started and know the place for the first time.
[hr]

Ultimately, I choose not to vote in this poll. It matters not whether God exists or not, in whatever form. If my beliefs are correct, then if I believed differently it wouldn't matter (though with different beleifs I wouldn't believe that). The inner, outer and non-worlds are interreflections of each other, so God (n)either exists or unexists throughout/throughin all of it. In the end, which is also the beginning, and yet neither, God/us/not will be God/us/not.

What I want is to live in the flow, to create the things I long to create/manifest without self-imposed obstacles blocking my path. Cave assectatorem Ductoris Alacris
